     Based on what I know of the C-type languages, the problem could be the 
range of numbers you're working with. Depending on how much memory the coder 
wanted to take up with each value, there are a set number of memory 
locations where the value sits. If it grows larger than the space allocated 
for it, the overflow is discarded.... or if it intrudes on another value, 
perhaps one used to run Glad.exe or Windows, you get a nice crash. To make 
things worse, at one end of your little rented space in memory there's a bit 
which tells the computer whether the number is positive or negative. If the 
value gets too high, it overflows into this area and you usually get a 
negative. That's what I assume happened to our archmages.
     One thing that I'm not quite sure on--which of your levels are so 
difficult? I can beat any of the ones you posted with a character below 
level 75. (Of course, the experience gained on the level usually puts me 
above 100.) I think that perhaps you should be steering yourself away from 
the this-is-a-job-for-SuperMage(TM) scenarios and make something with a more 
universal appeal.
     As for the rocks--I've had very large areas filled almost completely 
with those rocks that never vanish, and unless you're a cleric, blob, or 
orc, you can clear them out in a few minutes. Try an archer's barrage, or 
just blast away with a mage or archmage. Those rocks will vanish.
     I'm still having problems with chain lightning. Used correctly, without 
pushing any limits, it still brings my computer to a crawl. It's a nice 
chance to go get a drink, but it disrupts the role-playing realism. A lot. I 
don't know how it's coded, but it may be that there are some unnecessary 
calculations being done, slowing everything up. Or... is there a C object 
for each little bolt of lightning? Blech. There must be SOME way to make the 
lightning AI centralised... it's not my area of expertise so I won't try to 
figure it out. With poisoned darts and celery,     -Tevildo, Prince of Cats.
